36893111.review: Harmonia is a kinetic visual novel by Visual Arts Key who are known for their tear jerking visual novels. If you have an hour or three for a quick burn of a feel sad feel good kind of thing, then Harmonia is the game to read.

36796286.review:
*SPOILER FREE REVIEW*

Key is pretty much one of my fave companies of all time, as their content is whimsical, romantic, thought-provoking and fully of emotion.  Harmonia is another good example of what they can do.

Harmonia is a kinetic novel, meaning that there are no choices to make - it's more like reading a book or watching a DVD.  It took me about three hours to complete.  Technically speaking, there is only one slight issue that I can report - when I booted up the game for the first time, an error message occurred telling me that the game's default font was not available on my computer and I had to choose another one.  To be honest, this wasn't an issue as I could choose a new font with ease and it had no effect on the gameplay - I could start the game straight after choosing with no issue.  Just beware that you might have to choose a different font from the in-game menu.  No big deal though.

Story wise, Harmonia touches upon themes that Key have covered before, and a lot of people have criticised it for being too close to Key's other kinetic novel Planetarian.  After playing Harmonia, I can both agree and disagree with elements of that comparison.  When you put it down on paper, the similarities are astonishing; both stories feature a post-apocalyptic world caused by human error, where the protagonist wanders a desolate Earth, dealing with phenomena like acid rain from atmosphere pollution and attack from roving bandits.  Both stories also feature a type of humanoid android/robot/computer that has survived events so far and is attempting to fulfil its original purpose.  Both stories also feature a theme of fixing or rebuilding physical objects.  Both stories ALSO feature the struggle for survival and the emotional connotations of trying to help people even if it seems pointless given certain circumstances.  After reading all that, you'll probably agree that it doesn't look good for Harmonia being an original, fresh experience.

However, all of that being said, what makes Harmonia great in its own right is its story and characters.  Despite all of these similarities, as the story progressed and I was introduced to the different characters, their struggles and their experiences, I happily fell victim to what Key do best - making great, 3 dimensional, genuine and entrancing characters that you really grow to care about.  Despite noting myself at the beginning that the themes were similar to Planetarian, I quickly found myself forgetting about Planetarian completely and instead becoming attached to this group of characters that felt authentic and unique to Harmonia.  By the story ended, I felt like I'd really gone on a journey with these people and that it hadn't been like anything else, especially with the twist in the tale I did not suspect.  So in contrast to my earlier comparison, I genuinely recommend Harmonia because its story is its own, and it was very enjoyable.  Its CGs and soundtrack are also up to Key's usual memorable and effective par, and all in all, I'd say that Key are definitely on form with this kinetic novel.

34926218.review:
Rating: 7/10 ("Good")

Recommended for: People who enjoy VNs, people who enjoy post-apocalyptic futures, people who enjoy crying with their novels. I would recommend this to a first time VN reader.

Harmonia is short visual novel with around 6 hours of read time. There are no choices to be made; it's simply a VN to read and experience. One thing I noticed immediately upon starting the game is that the UI seems rather old what with the overlay of text over the entire image. That's not something you see in a lot of VNs released recently. Thankfully, you can remove the text to see the CG or background simply by hitting the spacebar.

The art in Harmonia is very pretty apart from one quibble I have; that would be Madd’s sprites. His nose is nonexistent and makes him look extremely unnatural. Everything else is fine and even beautiful, albeit it requires you to suspend your disbelief. For instance, how can Tipi have such long hair and wear such lovely clothes in this dystopian society? I know for sure that I wouldn’t want hair that long in a setting like that…it seems like too much work to take care of when I could be doing something else…but perhaps that is a sign of her true strength.

Jokes aside, Harmonia itself is a somewhat sombre game. Whilst there are certainly slice of life elements, it's a tragedy novel at its heart, meant to make you cry. You'll probably be pleased to hear that the ending is actually happy, in a way that fits. It's not overly optimistic but it does fit the themes and it's at least somewhat "realistic", as far as realism can go.

The plot itself is decent but feels a little too similar to Planetarian. There were plot aspects and scenes I could guess simply from reading that VN previously. And, after reading Harmonia, I can say that in my opinion Planetarian is the better of the two, but your mileage may vary. Some aspects that seemed very strange while first reading Harmonia make sense later on after finishing the story and understanding everything.

The characters in Harmonia are competently written, though they don't have an astounding amount of depth and some are rather unabashedly cliche.

The soundtrack is hit or miss. Some tracks were very beautiful and fitting to the scene, while I simply didn't care for others.

Overall, Harmonia is a decent visual novel that is a nice read, though I personally think Planetarian would be a better pick even with its shorter length.

33585807.review:
Ancora una volta Visual Arts/Key riesce a confezionare una VN, breve ma intensa... la tipica intensità che ha reso celebre questo sviluppatore nel prendere "a pugni nello stomaco" il lettore non prima di averlo viziato con pietanze preparate con dovizia di particolari e con ingredienti di ottima qualità.
Il flusso narrativo è cadenzato ottimamente e non travolge mai il lettore con nozionismi pesanti o descrizioni troppo prolisse (come ci si aspettarebbe da un setting totalmente sconosciuto e lontano dalla nostra quotidianità), gli eventi sono dosati con parsimonia, vista la lunghezza non eccessiva della novel, e i colpi di scena posti nei momenti più appropriati.
Il tratto è molto familiare, seppure non molto originale... pesca a piene mani dalla trazione Key, risultando forse troppo vicino a Rewrite (che speriamo arrivi al più presto su Steam) e prodotti recenti, ma riesce comunque a soddisfare l'occhio sebbene, parere personale, non abbia apprezzato la ripetività e lo sviluppo verticale degli stessi: usandoli a guisa di segnalibro mentre il testo si sviluppa a destra dello schermo; una rottura rispetto al classico sviluppo orizzontale con testo in basso, piacevole all'inizio, soffre della già accennata ripetitività e lascia che sia il solo testo a reggere tutto l'impianto della novel.

Gli effetti sono minimi, ma visto il tema trattato va benissimo così: non accenno in alcun modo alla storia, perché credo sia dannoso in una VN così breve; per chi l'avesse accostato a Planetarian, bé credo sia come accomunare qualsiasi storia o videogioco ambientato in un'epoca post-olacausto e pensare che siano tutte uguali.
Ci sono molti elementi comuni, ma per continuare l'analogia iniziale col cibo: è sempre un piatto di pasta, ma il resto degli ingredienti è totalmente diverso. :)

La traduzione di Key/VA riesce a portare il messaggio originale senza alcuna difficoltà, e i momenti di maggiore tensione emotiva arrivano al lettore senza alcun espediente particolare... il comparto audio non può brillare più di tanto, complice una soundtrack adeguata alla lunghezza della novel, ma il main theme e la sua versione vocal (tra l'altro cantata da Haruka Shimotsuki, una voce familiare per chi ricorda le opening/ending della serie Atelier) sono molto orecchiabili.

In definitiva, un ottimo lavoro per gli amanti delle Kinetic Novel brevi, come appunto Planetarian o Eden... per chi volesse qualcosa di più corposo, con route multiple e scelte meglio puntare su Clannad - Tomoyo After o Grisaia no Kajtsu. Io l'ho comprata coi saldi Steam al 60% e, a quel prezzo, non posso che consigliarla a qualunque avido lettore di VN.

33105477.review:
Bueno, para empezar...
Esta Visual Novel kinetic, que tiene una única historia sin rutas alternartivas, también corta, vale la pena dependiendo del público.

Para aquellos que buscan algo corto y una buena historia, les recomiendo, especialmente para los que buscan encontrar sentimientos, justamente esta historia habla sobre las emociones humanas.
La banda sonora me pareció buena, el arte visual también y el desarrollo de la historia (hubo algunas partes que me parecieron pesadas, pero pasan), todo lo bueno exceptuando dos cosas: [spoiler] el prefinal, justo lo antes al final siento que se necesitó desarrollo, y los fondos. [/spoiler]
Bueno, de hecho, los fondos cuando te encuentras en lugares públicos no me gusta mucho, solo los interiores de casas estaban pasables.

Si se buscan historias largas, no sabría qué decirte.

Y si en el caso de buscar cosas lindas, fanservice y pura comedia sin estar a lo serio, no se te recomienda la novela.

Lo calificaría como 7.8/10, para mí.
Pero en el conjunto de Key Studio, más o menos lo calificaría como 5.5/10.

Extra: Si has jugado ya a Planetarian y te gustó, puedes considerar esto como una historia paralela aunque se desarrollen en diferentes entornos, es recomendable en este caso.

[b] Harmonia :[/b]
  法语：异色
  拉丁语：和谐
  
    ——和谐的五彩斑斓的世界

    人类在生存中，是否已经忘却了什么东西？科技飞速发展的同时，是否让人类失去了本来锁应该存在的东西？
	『Harmonia』 一个令人警醒的温馨故事，正在等你来阅读。
	
  [i]//以下评测不涉及剧透[/i]
  
    剧情：
    经典Key社剧情，一波三折。没有最好的结局，确有最适合的结局。无分支、无选项，正统的有声小说。一共八章剧情+一个ED，在全程听语音的情况下，游戏时间至少为8小时。这个故事不适合在人多嘈杂的时候阅读，建议在空闲时间找个安静的地方游玩。
	
	音乐：
	可圈可点，AVG的BGM也是良好游戏感受中的一环。重点推荐主题歌，八音盒版本的和霜月遥唱的都很棒。霜月遥清灵的嗓音和八音盒配合，非常适合这个故事。[spoiler] 是的，我就是安利霜月遥的。【被pia飞】 [/spoiler] 
	
	关于汉化：
	感谢Xmoe汉化组的辛勤劳动，但是汉化补丁是基于C89版本的游戏制作的，不支持steam版本。如果有想挂时间的，推荐双开。[url=http://weibo.com/ttarticle/p/show?id=2309404121815587929756] 请支持正版，感谢Xmoe汉化组。 [/url]

今天是个让我非常开心的日子。不是因为某para3的发售，而是因为日语版Harmonia的面市。[spoiler]提前剁了两个月的手终于要看到成果啦，很期待初回特典的音乐盒[/spoiler]
5月26日这天对于Harmonia来说也算是一个有重要意义的日子，借此机会我就随便给这部作品写篇评测，从各个方面谈论一下这款KEY的最新作以及一些个人观点吧。

[b][u]游戏[/u][/b]：本部作品作为一部Kinetic Novel，没有对话选项，没有分支线，玩家就像在读一本有插图和配音配乐的小说。如果认真地推一遍差不多每章要花一个小时，就是说一共需要8小时的时间来完成剧情。游戏已经发售一年了，打折史低12元，还能掉卡，根据时长来说也算是很良心了。

[b][u]背景[/u][/b]：从Kanon、CLANNAD和planetarian到Rewrite再到本作Harmonia，描写从含蓄内敛到直白露骨，世界性的问题贯穿KEY社作品十八年。自然环境破坏，人口指数增长，资源严重短缺，人类利益冲突……KEY社藉由二次元委婉生动地描绘出了这些看似离我们的日常生活很遥远的问题。违背自然法则必定会遭受地球母亲的惩罚，将来的三次元会不会面临像本作中的世界那样毫无生机，未来的人类会不会生活在全球沙漠化的环境中，抬头只能看到被灰尘笼罩的天空，会不会像星之梦里的废墟猎人那样只能从书上和星象馆了解星空呢？

[b][u]画面[/u][/b]：人物的立绘采用手绘风格，仔细看人物身上的阴影还会闪动。室外背景图有许多浮灰颗粒，整体给人一种在沙漠地区的感觉，也很好的衬出故事背景：世界大战后的满目疮痍的景象。画面整体颇具亮点，美中不足的就是分辨率只有720P。[spoiler]难道是为以后动画化炒冷饭出Harmonia HD留后路吗？[/spoiler]

[b][u]音乐[/u][/b]：KSL音乐一向很不错，但说实话本作的音乐没有给我留下太深的印象。整体只能算是中规中矩。个人感觉唯一不错的就是ED《永遠の星へ》——汐奈伴着音乐盒的旋律温暖了整个小镇的永恒之歌。

[b][u]对比[/u][/b]：同为KEY社的Kinetic Novel，本作从故事背景来看和星之梦有些许相似之处。两者都有一定的科幻色彩，世界设定都是未来的战后，星之梦的世界满目疮痍看不到星空，本作的世界全球沙漠化让人很难生存。另外Phiroid和Android都是人类研发出来为自身服务的人形机器人，前者拥有后者所没有的重要的人类特征，也是本作重要的主题表现：情感。

[b][u]人设[/u][/b]：樋妈脸很有特色，一般刚接触会很排斥，不过时间久了就会发现变成自己最爱的风格了(切身体会)。本篇有两位女性角色，和蔼善良用歌声和笑容给人带来温暖的小天使“汐奈”(Shiona) 和忧郁可怜陷入无尽悲伤话音中总是带着哭腔的小萝莉“提比”(Tipi)[spoiler]提比酱是真的萌，楚楚可怜的形象很容易激起他人的保护欲，不是萝莉控的我都想抱走安慰了(*/∇\*)[/spoiler]

内容方面就不多废话了，剧情依然是KEY社熟悉的套路，大篇幅日常铺垫到高潮部分一波三折的剧情，从高潮到结尾先致郁后治愈，没什么可讲的。同音乐给我的印象一样，中规中矩。结尾的治愈算是给整体平淡的剧情一个亮点，并不是一般的大团圆GE，这点还是蛮赞的。


最后，以一些萌新的个人感想结尾，为本作投上微不足道的一票好评，希望KEY可以在未来为玩家带来更多的治愈和感动。
[h1]Kanon是奇迹
AIR是轮回
CLANNAD是人生
planetarian是传承
Little Busters!是友情
Rewrite是生命
Angel Beats!是青春
Harmonia是情感
GalGame离不开爱情，可这些作品的主题不都是爱情
是KEY让我了解了二次元不是只有废萌卖肉德国骨科
而是存在真正可以治愈心灵的一方净土。

开头那两句英文是KEY写给Harmonia的，我也想把它送还给KEY
希望KEY社是一首可以一直传唱下去的永恒之歌。[/h1]

31946923.review:
Harmonia is a kinetic visual novel that takes place in the distant future when the world has been devastated.  The land is dry and barren, the skies are continually sandy (when it's not raining), and humans struggle just to survive.  In Harmonia, you learn about this world from a boy later called Rei, and he awakens from a deep sleep in some sort of factory.  Upon gazing at his mechanical right hand, Rei comes upon the conclusion that he is a Phiroid, an android that looks like a human and is capable of exhibiting human emotions and feelings-pretty much can function as a human although the interior of Phiroids is clearly different from those of humans.  As Rei has woken up without experiencing emotions, he leaves the factory to search for humans who can help him experience them.  Along this journey, a girl named Shiona finds him and helps him to experience emotions along with a few notable townspeople whom Rei encounters and interacts with in the town where Shiona lives.  I'll leave off the summary at that, as I don't want to spoil anything and it's best to get the game and experience the story for yourself.  ;)

Now on to my review of Harmonia.  I found the story to be very beautiful and moving, as Rei got to experience the feelings of joy, anger, sadness, etc.  I was really moved to see how much Rei wanted to help Shiona and the other townspeople-to bring smiles to their faces.  Especially towards the end, I was crying quite a lot and that's because [spoiler]Rei finally experienced love from Shiona and after Shiona died, Rei makes a vow to himself to find a world where humans and Phiroids could live happily together, as the world he is in now is one in which humans (in general) hate Phiroids because they lack love.[/spoiler]  If you've ever played planetarian~the reverie of a little planet~, then you'll understand the emotions that the devs of both games can bring out from those who experience these beautiful stories.  The art was beautiful and I really loved the music.  If there are any criticisms, they're technical things and only a couple of minor ones.  First, I had to play Harmonia in full screen mode because the windowed mode looked weird.  It was kind of difficult to view the game in windowed mode so I had to play it in full screen mode.  However, I think that Harmonia is better experienced in full screen mode so I don't consider this too much of a negative.  Also, when I started up the game, I had to choose a font which was weird since the font should be automatically installed in visual novels.  Fortunately, I was able to choose a font from which I could read the story and then it worked out fine.  Other than those two issues, I have no other criticisms.  I like how you can go back to replay certain chapters, and the CG gallery and music options are unlocked after you complete the game.

Overall, I really loved Harmonia and it's definitely up there with some of my all-time favorite visual novels.  It's a story that will touch your heart, get you to experience feelings like Rei does, and it's definitely worth getting if you like visual novels and a wonderful, beautiful story.  ^^

30956164.review:
[h1]The world in harmony[/h1]
Harmonia is a kinetic novel (VN with only one route and no choices to make) from prolific studio Key. Having awoken from stasis, the robotic protagonist must learn to adapt to the clinging remnants of humanity present in a post-apocalyptic world.

[b]Plot[/b]
I'll be addressing the storyline first as it is the most crucial aspect. While it does not start with the most creative premise, the story soon becomes more complicated and endearing. Unfortunately the story is too short to accommodate for much character development, so most people end up as flat as they started. 

Perhaps also due to its brevity, the game is riddled with pacing issues. Individual chapters retain a very sharp focus on only one character at a time. Also, for the majority of the story very little is at stake. Suddenly everything ramps up at the last hour but then each problem neatly and quickly resolves itself. 

[b]Visual[/b]
Anyone familiar with Key's other works will immediately notice a marked improvement on character portraits. The more contemporary art style is more soothing and pleasant than anything they've drawn before.

[b]Sound[/b]
A handful of moving songs, and even one fully composed with lyrics. An impressive amount of work went into making sure everything sounded and looked great. 

[b]Three stars out of five[/b]
Harmonia has about five hours worth of reading, making it the perfect size to dip your toes into.

Personally though I preferred their earlier work, Planetarian. The character's are more developed, the plot is more interesting, and there's a much more vivid sense of dread and suspense. If you enjoyed that then come back and play Harmonia.

30888356.review:
A brand new Visual Novel from VisualArts/Key which heavily focuses on emotions, mainly happiness, sadness, anger and love. 

[b]Graphics: 9/10[/b]

Harmonia has a very modern art style which is a step-up from their previous works; I’m mainly comparing it with planetarian and Clannad. The characters are all drawn beautifully, but the same cannot be said with a lot of the locations; they seemed “average” compared to the rest of the art work. 

[b]Storyline: 7/10[/b]

It is very much like planetarian from start to finish. It had a very similar setting (a futuristic, “broken” world where survival is a priority) and the ‘boy’ coming across a town full of [spoiler]Phiriods[/spoiler] as does the main character from planetarian as he discovers a place where he finds a ‘non-human’. It’s all too similar and I find that VisualArts/Key didn’t try to come up with something a little different. But that’s not to say that the entire story was “bad” and “copied over”. Although, the first 5 chapters starts off slow. But it does pick up rather quickly from chapter 6 – 8; almost too quickly because a lot of information gets told in a matter of lines and scenes. I really felt like they rushed the ending. Nonetheless, the story isn’t bad, but it could’ve done a lot better. 

[b]Sound: 9/10[/b]

Simply amazing. It doesn’t have that much soundtracks when I checked, but I was still impressed on how they used those soundtracks in the VN. Each specific scene had their own soundtrack depending on the situation. It’s almost has if they were ‘themes’ dedicated to a character or location. 

[b]Gameplay: 9/10[/b]

Slight issues with the font settings from the start (I fiddled almost 20 mins trying to figure out how to make the fonts even show up, as they could not be read). But once sorted, it was smooth sailing from there. No lag, crashes or UI defects to report.

[b]Price: 10/10[/b]

For £6.99 it’s a great deal, it’s not asking for a lot (compared to other VNs). Its guaranteed to give you an experience like planetarian with some slight improvements here and there. If you haven’t read planetarian, this VN will give you a completely different experience from all the other VNs out there.

虽然一发售左右就买了，但还是拖到了昨天才玩通。galgame基本只玩key社的，从clannad、little busters、rewrite、angel beats到星之梦再到harmonia。我不知评论说什么好，也不知有什么标准，但就个人而言，是绝对的好评的。大概从下面几个方面说下我的感受吧。
[list]
     [*][h1] 语言与游戏模式 [/h1] 
一开始玩英文版的galgame是比较抗拒的，也想着等日文版或汉化版在玩，但还是没忍住开始玩。对于有点日语基础的我，刚开始还是有点奇妙的感觉的，中日英三种语言在脑中切换，后面渐渐习惯后就好了，有语音就中日切换，没有就中英切换。有人会说英语不好玩不下去，我觉得这问题真的不大。加上一个有屏幕取词翻译的软件就能轻松理解大意了。[spoiler]  我用的是有道词典[/spoiler] 另一方面，对于这种没有选项的模式，在星之梦里体验过一次就还好，可以安心看剧情而不必苦恼怎么走线。嘛，或许对其他人来说就不太喜欢就是了。
    [*][h1]音乐 [/h1] 
这个我还能说什么，key社的音乐从来就没让我失望过。或许我要求低，不管别人怎么说，我依旧喜欢。玩通后配合歌词听那两首有歌词的歌，也会有一番感叹。唯一有点不满的就是里面的music mode里的bgm不全，少了届けたいメロディ以及Halitus只收录了一个版本，所以我只好从游戏里的文件找出来听。
    [*][h1]剧情 [/h1] 
剧情方面我一直都不擅长总结，就不多说。我只能说我玩到后面被感动的一塌糊涂，多少有星之梦的影子，但个人而言，要比星之梦好一点。有点小抱怨就是游戏长度不够长，我已经放慢速度玩，还是十来小时结束了，有点不舍。
   [*][h1]画面与人设 [/h1] 
一句话，我很喜欢。
[/list]

28884556.review:
Not my favorite game from [i]key[/i], but not terrible either.

The music is beautiful, and the artwork is gorgeous, but the story was rather disappointing.  I've had mixed feelings about [i]key[/i]'s works in the past:  I loved Planetarian, Clannad, and Angel Beats, but wasn't so fond of Kanon, Little Busters and now Harmonia.

The theme this time is feelings or emotions.  Our protaganist has awoken without his, and most of the early story is about how he rediscovers various emotions.  Most of these chapters end up feeling disjointed, often focusing on a single character, which ends up hurting the pacing.  The end of the story is reminiscent of Planetarian, but feels more like they just needed a plot device to get to the reveal.  Once there, I found that reveal to be even more contrived than the reused plot device.  I do recognize that part of my dissatisfaction here was related to my understanding of the philosophical issues that they're trying to use as the foundation of their story, so it's likely to not be as annoying to most people.

Other people have mentioned that Harmonia reminds them of Planetarian.  We have the post-apocalyptic future with only androids and humans remaining, but that was the end of the similarity for me.  While the setting is certainly a match, the story and characters in Planetarian have more depth than was managed here.  Each character is pretty much limited to a single emotion for the entire story, which makes it hard to grow really attached to any of them.  [i]key[/i]'s works focus on getting the audience to invest in the characters; so if you don't or can't empathize with the characters, the stories just aren't satisfying.

The artwork was wonderful.  Most of it retains a slight pencil & watercolor look to it instead of looking purely digital.  They also added an subtle effect of moving pencil shading over the images, which I particularly liked for some reason.  The music was simple but sweet and generally fit the scene.  However, I didn't come away terribly attached to it.  Having the full soundtrack for DLC would be nice, but I'm not going to miss it.  The one thing that consistantly annoyed me about the music was that they waited unitl the very end of the game to use the main theme song with vocals.  Despite multiple scenes where it would have been applicable and could have been used to better effect.  Instead it was tossed in at the climax to try to make the ending as emotional as possible.  Disappointingly, we were not given subtitles for the main theme, though we do get them for the ending theme song.

Overall, I don't think it was a bad game--I've seen much worse for more money--but it's not one I'd really recommend either.  $10 for a short novel is reasonable, but the story was just too weak for my tastes.

Note:  Look in the Harmonia\bgm folder for an Ogg Vorbis version of the soundtrack.

27670036.review:
拖拖拉拉玩了大概两个多星期，当时闲的无聊看了下Key的百科，发现今年竟然新出了一个英文的AVG游戏，恩，果断剁手。
好了废话不多说，本体是个电子小说，也就无关分支和角色路线，作为看官，能做的不过是轻点鼠标轻敲键盘，BGM真的很棒，让人情不自禁的在脑内reverberate，剧情方面还是一如既往的在前面埋下伏笔，然后等到结局的时候才解密，因而在欣赏前面几章的时候有可能会因为太过日常而有些无趣，在中间几章剧情紧张度骤然上升，所以建议要坚持玩下去，玩到最后还是相当感人的（虽然对于泪点高的并没有哭，但多少算是有点触动）。
作为泣系游戏（而且非18X TAT）,在蛰伏一年后KEY社仍然交出了一份满意的成果。就我个人而言，感觉自从Rewrite后Key社的主题不再只是着眼于儿女情长，提高到了更为深刻的对人性（善与恶，emotion的演化）以及人与自然之间关系的剖析，正如小标题所说”You taught me how important feelings are. There is an everlasting song”，有feeling和emotion才能称之为人，而feeling和emotion是人类世代相传的传颂之物。

27024084.review: Key never fails to impress me. As a kinetic visual novel, it tells a cohesive apocalyptic story, that would by the end, leave you in tears.

26756648.review:
I've been a big fan of Key for ten years, but I have to say I was hesitant to read this. Unlike many people, I didn't LOVE Planetarian, and this seemed like it was going to be Planetarian 2.0. It kind of is, both stories are post-apocolyptic robot fantasy dramas, but Harmonia to me is far more interesting. It deals with a lot of new subject matters for Key, particularly the nature of being human and how we as a species treat the earth we live on. It's not the same old visual novel stuff, it feels fresh, whilst still retaining that classic Key feel. 
There were many poignant moments and a great plot twist. I have mixed feelings on the ending looking back, but it was definitely very interesting and unexpected. I'd recommend Harmonia to a visual novel virgin, it's a well-paced impactful story, and I'm glad I've finally experienced it.

26536411.review:
时值11-11，偶然打开steam，翻到Harmonia的界面，看着各位dalao的测评，突然想写点什么，也算是打发下时间。
 
正好昨天上网翻到了Harmonia的制作过程，在这里简单概括一下吧，毕竟这次的企划说到底还是有点特殊的。
首先，必须提到Key的母公司Visual Art’s（下简称VA）及其社长马场隆博，因为这次的企划、包括这次的steam版先行发售，基本上是由马场在推进。
其次，是脚本栏的“中村缀”，因为追根求源的话，他才是Harmonia故事的最初创作者。
按照时间顺序理一下：
1.	VA社发起活动【Kinetic小说大赏】，中村缀提出作品【届けたいメロディー】（没看错，就是主题曲），由于文笔较为拙劣且有矛盾&疑点，并没有获奖。
2.	马场认为【届けたいメロディー】的世界观与Key相一致，想将其作为Kinetic小说出版。遂任命在大赏中担任评委的魁（CL双子+胜平、AB1岩泽）为制作指挥。
3.	2014-7，马场同魁与中村缀交涉，并获得修改并提升原案的许可。
4.	Harmonia制作中，并首次采用在VA系游戏中没有的纵写式。
5.	2015年，巴黎Japan EXPO中，马场宣布Harmonia将先行发售英文版。
6.	Harmonia英文版与日文版final β版几乎完美按照日程表同时制作完成。
7.	2015年底，由于马场对世界观说明与效果音不满意，游戏跳票。
8.	2016-9-23，面向海外玩家的英文版在steam上线。
9.	2016-11-10，宣布日文版将在C91（161229）中与Key商品合并在Key-set中发售。

所以和星之梦的区别就是：凉元悠一可是正经的高水平小说家出身（毕竟认证久弥厨），而且在星之梦之前已经有AIR的SUMMER篇和CL的琴美线，而中村缀只是一名名不见经传的写手吧。

大体就是这样吧。

该说回游戏了。

恩，先说画。（阴险+滑稽）
樋妈强无敌！（拖走）
相比以前的各大作品，这次樋妈几乎是完美发挥（全部立绘甚至包括CG都没有任何违和感）
咸菜PRPR，TP prpr。
结果樋妈在发售前3天离开了我键……………

再说音乐。
强！无敌！OST出了就买买买！！！
本来理论上5H的剧本，我愣是推了10H，几乎都是在放慢单循。
Terrarum, Oppidum（这2曲我个人给满分，Terrarum的后期爆发让我想起了Scene shifts there，而且乐器选的感觉非常舒服；Oppidum则是完美地和荒漠小镇的气氛融为一体，极易单循且很难出来，这曲也是我决定买OST的最大动力）, Cantus, Library, Halitus.
两首歌也都出来一年了，就不说了。

最后说剧情（剧透）
初看起来是和星之梦一个套路
[spoiler] 然而是反套路，没有感情的男主居然是一直向拥有其他仅仅拥有一种感情的机器人们学习感情的人类，这就显得十分的讽刺。参考弹丸希望之峰系列中，众ALTER EGO的出众表现、I/O中2台量子计算机恋爱引发的故事，可以说人工智能和人类在未来的界限是否会只有‘多细胞生命体’这个最根本区别呢？[/spoiler]
[spoiler]前期的铺垫可以说做得非常的好，无论是八音盒、画、还是录像，从シオナ到ティピィ到マッド，男主对于感情逐渐的认知与感受，都能让玩家（至少我是）沉浸在里面。[/spoiler]
[spoiler]然后就是后期的展开，虽然收尾可能显得比较仓促【感觉这点有点可惜】，不过男主在即将休眠的咸菜旁，收获了人类最重要的情感“爱”，然后才踏上旅途的。[/spoiler]
[spoiler]爱的意义，相信玩过Rewrite的人是很有感触的，那可是连Moon的朗哥都不能解读的存在，被封锁于超高次元的知性之中，可见其地位。[/spoiler]
[spoiler]最后，也算是NE了吧（苦笑）[/spoiler]
一句话，买买买，给我键续1s吧（黑框眼镜滑稽）

26377546.review:
Harmonia is a very short Visual Novel by Key, one of most popular and successful VN developers in the business. It's a short story about the relationships between humans and androids in a post-apocalyptic earth. It's a very well executed game, with wonderful production values, memorable music, and some really wonderful HD visuals, but the writing is clumsy at parts. The whole moral of the story, which is intrinsically tied to a rather obvious plot twist, comes across and very forced to an unbelievable degree. I understand that the game isn't very long, so they didn't have much time to flesh out the smaller details, but I found it very hollow and flat.

Harmonia could be said to be a spiritual successor of sorts to Key's previous short VN, Planetarian, which I do believe is the better game, and would recommend reading before this one. Planetarian was another short, atmospheric story, but I found the themes to be better handled in that one. I must admit, however, that Harmonia is one gorgeous game- Probably the most beautiful looking and sounding Key game on Steam, and I think the eye-candy alone is worth the price of admission.

After playing Planetarian first, Harmonia had a tough act to follow. The set-up was good, it got a little dry partway through, and, for me, the plot twist made the story suddenly fall into chaotic array, so much so that it made me lose a sense of immersion in the narrative, or in stuff that made sense. It also didn't really connect back to Planetarian, so it's more like a spiritual sequel than a narrative/elsewhere story sort of sequel.
That said, I did enjoy the characters for the most part, and the story up until the immersion-breaking twist. However, coming from the Clannad anime and Planetarian, I was a little TOO prepared to really succumb to any sort of heart-clutching feels.

26092120.review:
Harmonia is a Kinetic Novel (for them who don't know the difference between Kinetic and Visual novels, Kinetic are a fixed story where as visual offer multiple choices which commonly offer different endings) in which you play as Rei, Rei wakes up one day in a abandoned factory out in what seems to be the middle of nowhere, after collpasing trying to find humans you are recused and come to live in the town. The story follows Rei's interactions and development of emotions (which he has lost) and his understanding of new feelings... but he can't help shake the feeling something is wrong, the towns people seem off time to time and Shiona seems to be hiding something, and then there is the lonely girl Tipi...

The story essentially breaks into 3 small Arcs, Madd, Tipi and Shiona (though Shiona's and Tipi's are sort of merged into a close one, these 3 arcs also are the highlight of the game, for spoiler reasons i wont mention what is what with them but they are essentially your onion cutting moments. The ending for me was great, tear jerking and well told, you really felt like you was involved in the scene and if you have grown to like the characters, you will likely be shedding them tears here, the game does offer and additional epilouge which i felt was a bit 'meh', most commend it greatly and love it but i feel it ruins the previous scenes. 

The art in Harmonia is brilliant to say the least, especially the character designs, i can be picky at times over what i like when looking at characters but this game did an amazing job, this goes equally for sound, the sound commonly sets the mood very well and even when you are in no special situation, you get a feel for the world around you just by the sound.

I wont deny, the game does get off to a slowish start, which it isn't bad, it doesn't really pull you in either, in fact, the Library was the first trigger to my attention as Tipi actually got me interested in her, especially when you see others reactions to seeing her. Needless to say, whilst the first chapter might not be the most interesting, don't knock the game, things get into full swing here and you will find yourself curiously addidicted to finding out what happens. 

As a whole, for the small price you pay for the game i would deffinetly recommend it, the game seems to average an average of about 6-8 hours gameplay (i have played it twice but don't let my time deiceve you, i had no net at first so it didn't log the hours) and the first was about 6-7hours with the second being a little longer (probably due to breaks) but it is 7 hours of great emotional story tellings you wont want to miss.

Can't help but compare this to Planetarian. Both are post-apocalyptic/dystopian setting and both deal with co-existence with humans and robots (Philoids in this case).

Planetarian is way better. but that's not to say Harmonia isn't anywhere bad. Without spoiling the major plot points, Planetarian pulled a big irony on the reader, and that irony is heavily implied that it will continue after the interaction of the two mains. Oh, and how relevant that pull is in the dystopian setting. In Harmonia however the biggest pull they made is arguably irrelevant to the bigger picture of the dystopian world setting.

Still I'm giving this a thumbs up. It did made me sit down for the entire latter half of the novel. My personal advice is that if you have to choose between the two, ask yourself if you want the beginner level (Harmonia) or the expert level (Planetarian). Oh, and visual-wise (since both titles are VISUAL novels after all), Harmonia is better hands down.

26021684.review:
[i]Harmonia[/i] is a kinetic novel that delivers the standard Visual Art / Key package of art, sound and story. There is a variety of backgrounds and character poses, all of which are well drawn and designed to convey the scene. The background music is easy to listen to and does not feel repetitive. A couple of the tracks are songs. Only three characters are voiced, and their voices suit their personalities.

It took a little over 5 hours to complete [i]Harmonia[/i], which makes it a bit longer than  [i]Planetarian[/i] (completed in about 4 hours), another Visual Art / Key kinetic novel. The story of [i]Harmonia[/i] does not have any significantly new or different experiences from previous Visual Art / Key works, so if this is not your first then you have an idea of what type of story to expect.  If this is your first, then without spoiling any specific plot details, you can expect two things: one, descriptions of the characters’ regular daily activities to let you relate to them, and two, a plot twist to tug at your heartstrings.

Overall, [i]Harmonia[/i] is a safe release to commemorate Key’s 15th anniversary because it reaffirms what Visual Art/ Key works are about.

25932375.review:
sin spoilers
no tiene sentido comparar esta visual novel con planetarian, no tiene nada que ver ni cerca, es buscarle el pelo al huevo, la postura del protagonista y de la chica en la historia, que haya mas de 2 personajes, ya es una experiencia totalmente diferente.

no suelo comprar visual novels, pero le tengo mucho aprecio a key, y como agradecimiento del lanzamiento en ingles antes de que salga en japones tuve q hacerlo, como para que de este lado del mundo sepan que también apoyamos su trabajo

los sentimientos es algo importante en la plot, te hace dudar de muchas cosas de la historia constantemente. si los personajes están enojados los sentís, si están tristes, si están felices.
mismo el protagonista, representa muy bien sus sentimientos y te los transmite a la perfección con palabras. 
alguien que esta siempre feliz, alguien que esta siempre enojado, alguien que esta siempre triste, te cruzas con personajes que parecen ser representaciones de los sentimientos a la perfección

la kinetic novel juega con tus propios sentimientos también, las razones del protagonista que lo hacen ir hacia adelante, como una persona que no sabe nada de sentimientos busca que todos sonrían porque entiende que cuando ellos sonríen, él se siente bien. y en eso se basa la novela, en él yendo de personaje en personaje realizando acciones pequeñas pero muy importantes para que el resto sea feliz

los dibujos de los personajes, con pequeños trazos negros como si fueran dibujados con lapiz (así parecidos a los del juego valkyria chronicles) son perfectos para la estética de la visual novel, y que tengan movimientos y no estén estáticos también hace a los personajes muy vivos

los tonos de gris, de sombra y luz es muy importante

en cuanto a los diseños de personajes, madd no me gusto,no esta muy detallado comparado con el resto. pero en general están bien 

las voces son perfectas y la música también, tipi actúa muy bien no la había escuchado en visual novels.
tipi es un personaje que habla, la vez, y ya te pones a llorar, te rompe el alma y no sabes porque, y eso también es un poco el juego que hace esta visual novel con vos, cuando shiona esta en pantalla estas feliz, estas alegre, cuando tipi esta no, la música, el ambiente y los personajes juegan con tu corazón

tiene onda como kinetic novel, no se si garpaba para tener desiciones

no le encontré algo como para criticarla, la historia quizás es lo mas flojo comparandola con el resto de los apartados que te ofrece el juego pero eso no es hablar mal de la historia, que es coherente y firme

siempre me mantuvo atrapado, en ningún momento flaqueo, no tiene muchas idas y vueltas al pedo, todo esta bien guionado y armado

uno tiene mas sentimientos cuando se enfrenta a los sentimientos de otras personas.

las cgs son lindos aunque escasos

mucho de la historia gira en torno a la analogía de "reparar lo que esta roto" que hace feliz a las personas y sobre el amor, la capacidad de amar.

a la mitad maso menos te empiezan a poner incomodo algunas situaciones, con suspenso, empezás a no entender a los personajes, hay cosas que te ocultan, que no te dicen, eso hace a la kinetic novel mas y mas atrapante.

la historia tiene un pacing tranquilo, no te presenta un camino fijo la verdad así que no esperas a que se termine de golpe, los primeros capítulos son mucho mas largos que el resto, y realmente el final me gusto mucho, no por los giros si no por como cerraron las cosas realmente

como persona que habla los 3 idiomas, ingles/japones/español, hay algunas cosas que se pierden en la traducción, pero escuchando a los personajes se entiende mejor.

vale mucho la pena.

si les interesan mas analisis sobre juegos o animes no duden en buscar mi pagina de facebook A-1 Pergo o seguirme en twitter /elpergo @elpergo

25921600.review:
Loved it, really worth waiting for, Key as usual hitting the right notes in their VN's, but I still think Planetarian is in a league of its own despite its age, regardless I think if you like one you'll certainly like the other.

8/10

Shinji Orito once again graces us with a soundtrack for this kinetic novel, which sits quite nicely, even when it takes the centre stage it stands up on its own, but it might do so too often for some, seems like its just the one song that gets the limelight, that said gotta praise the background music, it wasnt at all intrusive and fits the setting nicely, but then again maybe its too subtle if you compare to other Key works which isnt fair agaist 30+ hour VNs like Clannad but against its predecesor Planetarian seems like its been toned down, all the same flavour (every other song is a music box), even with Ryo Mizutsuki's compositions in the mix, or it could be said flows together from one scene too the next very smoothly depending on your on perspective.

The Art is well suited for the setting, it gives off a rustic, shadowy, post-apocalyptic feel with the shading and yet at the same time manages to keep the brightness of the characters that we see in most VN's giving their expressions that bit of shine to them, along with the backgrounds are particle effects working its magic in the right places to bring the scenes to life and a colour palate to match a dry lifeless world. Although there is one instance of animation throw in which feels quite out of place overall impressions are good. 

The story is well planned, but as some have said the characters at times feel 1 dimensional like theyve just been rolled in without giving them a great sense of depth despite spending time exploring the characters backgrounds, interacting with them throughout and giving them distinct personalities which play into the story it doesnt give a lot of (unforced) memorable drama or tension between them, however the story alway kept me guessing at what is going to happen next although some event are foreshadowed quite obviously the reveals are moments of clarity that you can guess at but not quite reach, hovering just on the edge of your thoughts, a sort of play on the ego that has the potential to leave one feeling quite profound, making it very fun to follow from start to finish.

Not sure how I feel about the shifting layout, yes it fits, its in the right place for each scene but personally Im not a fan of a text box covering the image (as seen in the images been shown) and having to press space bar just to check it out, then fiddling with autoplay wondering if its working on not, squinting to see if the brightness has changed on the symbol made it a little arkward.

A solid VN from Key, and as always a tear jearking story, but hmmm, if I had to say Harmonia or Lucy: The Eternity She Wished For... then, Planetarian... quite hard not to compare the two Key Kinetic novels and when I think of Anderoids/Phiroids in VNs on Steam I also think of Lucy despite it not being a kinetic novel for me a comparison is unavoidable especially with them being the same price, At the end of the day Harmonia comes 3rd place out of these but this doesnt make it a bad VN and is certainly worth experiencing.

Maybe I've made it sound a bit harsh I'd still give it a respectable 8/10.

25835332.review:
Harmonia is about a robot with the appearance of a teenage boy leaving the tomb of his forgotten brethren to find the outside world, as he does, he finds that the world itself is dead and barren. Overtime he reaches a town with people and starts living in the towns church. He attempts to hide his robotic nature so he can be of service to humans, but lacks emotions making it a complicated issue, the story takes you on a journey to discover these emotions and why they are significant while also showing us how to care for each other. It emphasizes good intentions even when it may not always seem to be, but the world heavily contrasts these emotional states. May it be caring for people of the town or strangers, the town gives this warmness, but the world shows only the reverse. 
 
Alike to the above mentioned Planitarian the reverie of a little planet, this story focuses not on the robots or humans. Rather the story is about helping one another. Alike to Planitarian the main character only wishes to provide the most help he can give, at times neglecting himself. As the story progresses emotions change and so does the town and its people as they all grow to some extent. Though there is not much interactivity for the reader being a kinetic visual novel, it's easy to see from the main characters point of view, which in turn allows not only just the characters to go on this adventure, but the reader as well. When in comparison to Keys other works this one is clearly one to grab. My other recommendations include Planitarian my favorite of Keys works, which is now also a film and anime. You also have their biggest and most popular creation Clannad and its addition Tomoyo After, which also have been made into multiple animes and other medias.  You also have Angle Beats and Charlotte which though are amazing are primarily animes. 
 
In conclusion, this game has the same impact that Key is known for with their Kinetic novels making you feel strong emotions primarily sadness which causes the Novel to be a great and fond memory for the readers. Along with the professional design of the stories many parts including the music, art, and voice. You are sure to have an entertaining and engrossing read that stimulates your mind to think and continue reading till finished. Lastly I would once more like to recommend Planitarian: the Reverie of a little planet, the shortest Key novel, but I think the gem in the rough. Alike to the others it carries the amazing story along with the above elements. Specifically I like to note that the music will never leave your memory after playing it. Planitarian though having no connection in lore to this game goes hand in hand due to their closeness in themes and their design. 
 
Thank you for reading this review and I hope that you will find as much joy as I did with this product.
 I also like to thank Key for another job well done.

I read Harmonia, and... I'm not really sure how I feel about it. Maybe in a few years from now I'll see it differently. ^^,
The art was great, the music enhanced the experience, the voice acting was good, and I liked the characters. The story was... mmm, short but meaningful.
I read Harmonia mostly because some of the illustrations drew me in and, given that I enjoyed most of Key's other VNs (I read Little Busters!, Clannad and Rewrite) Harmonia being released on Steam gave me a chance to support Key in their latest endeavors without buying something I've already read.
Wrapping up I can say Harmonia was short, but good. It took me about 8 hours to finish it, but you can definitely finish it in less. It felt a little like a children's tale for the first 4 or so chapters, but then abruptly got a bit heavier. Should you buy it? If you like Key's works then yes you should, their stories have gotten me through some tough times. :) If you haven't read a Key VN/KN before, and you're on the fence, then Harmonia might not be a bad place to start, it definitely has a distinct Keyesque style and might give you an idea of what to expect from their longer works.
That being said I hope this review was helpful to you in some way and have a good one.

However, because its new kinetic novel, i cant help, but to compare it to minori's kinetic VNs eden* and Supipara.

You cant even start comparing Harmonia to Supipara, because that game is in entirely another league.

So this is positive review, because Harmonia is good game (mutch better then many other VNs with 10€ price tag), but you should also check minori's VNs ! :)

25782665.review:
Harmonia - последняя на сегодняшний день работа студии Key,релиз которой долго откладывался.И это в какой то степени похвально,всё же выпускать сырую новеллу для именитой студии глупо, да и в глазах фанатов можно было опуститься.Но вот она вышла и осталось только узнать,стоили  того ожидания? 
[h1]Сюжет[/h1]
  [i]События новеллы происходят в разрушенном мире, где естественные и искусственные роботы с фальшивыми воспоминаниями живут вместе. Роботов называют Фироидами. Главный герой — Рэй, и он является одним из этих роботов,но в добавок,он не может проявлять эмоции .После некоторого путешествия он встречает Сиону и Типи и он постепенно начинает меняться...[/i]
Сюжет делится на два этапа, с 1 по 6 главу и 7-8 главу. Первые 6 мы будем помогать другим людям становиться счастливее,возвращать  им потерянные эмоции, а так же знакомиться с миром. Как по мне весьма затянутые главы,интересно становится где то, может с 5 главы,до этого просто «никак» написанный текст.С 6 по 8 наступает сюжетный твист,и все вопросы которые были до этого,моментально исчезают.Эта часть мне больше всех понравилась,ибо она просто лучше написана и интересней,чем начало.Концовка быстрая,но «теплая».
[h1]Музыка[/h1]
Там где текст проседал,спасала музыка,ибо тут она очень годно написана и играла в нужном месте и «держало» настроение игры .Орито и Мизудзуки  постарались,заглавная и песня «грусти» получились очень атмосферные.Если выйдет отдельный OST,обязательно его куплю.
[h1]Визуальное оформление[/h1]
Всё достаточно мило,красиво.Задники тоже хороши ,если не приближать.Итару классно рисует,но вот некоторые позы вызывают у меня много вопросов.Анимированная штриховка на спрайтах выглядит странно,но не могу сказать что прям это лишнее,просто странно.
[h1]Ожидания [/h1]
Скорее оправдались,чем нет.Если бы не проседающее начало,было бы просто здорово. 
-Чисто моё мнение-
Авторам стойло бы сделать начало короче,а вторую половину больше,либо укоротить начало вовсе,ну просто "никак" написано,серьезно.
[h1]Итог[/h1]
Может показаться,что критикую слишком уж дотошно,но новелла мне всё же понравилась.Тут есть хорошие идеи,но некоторые из них плохо реализованы.Первое впечатление было «не очень»,но потом сюжет все же вышел в то русло,которое нужно.Ну и Кеевская концовка тоже решает.
Рекомендую всем фанатам этой студии.

This second kinetic visual novel from Visual Art's and Key feature a male protagonist Rei who woke up in an abandoned Phiroid factory with some recollection of Phiroids and their roles and existence alongside humans. Thinking himself to be a Phiroid from his mechanical hand, Rei wandered outside into a barren and hostile environment and was rescued and brought into a town with water supply by a female church pastor Shiona. While at the town, Rei got to know the inhabitants and gradually learned to express various emotions he had not felt before. 

Although there are no choices to make at all in this game, the CG, soundtracks, and overall game presentation are nicely done. Reading through the storyline and dialogue, unlocking the CG and music gallery and obtaining all achievements will take about 2 hours.

25720477.review:
I'm quite a huge fan of Key as a studio.  Rewrite and Little Busters! are some of my favorite games of all time (despite them just being Visual Novels). I have played most, if not all, of the Key Visual novels (aside from the extremely heavy adult ones because playing the 18+ version of Kanon almost ruined one of my favorite characters.).  

When I heard about Harmonia, I was pretty excited to see that It would be getting an official English release on steam, not that it matters to me since I can competently read Japanese.  With English being my native tough, however, there are certainly times when reading a Japanese text can leave me a little lost (mostly due to slang and wordplay).  Unlike many of the Key library, Harmonia is a Kinetic Novel; you don't have any choices, you just read, look and listen.  Also, like Planetarian before it, it is quite short clocking in at about 3-6 hours depending on how fast you read. 

The music is quite amazing, as expected of Key; there are some extremely strong tracks here that are very memorable and really good at setting the mood.  The story follows the usual Key formulae of being a "crying game".  The first few acts are slow and mainly for character development. The final few acts are where the emotional "shit hits the fan", as they say.  The voice acting is superb as expected and the art is very impactful with some panels being extremely vivid and memorable. Character design follows the typical "moe" style that Key is known for though don't be fooled; the characters are designed this way so that you will grow attached much easier.  Then when the story decides to rip your heart out of your chest and stamp on it multiple times you will be even more devastated.        

If you like Key and like visual novels then this is definitely worth it at 7 dollars. Bring a box of kleenex when you read Harmonia (not the happy kind) and enjoy the ride.

25714773.review: This is the first VN I've read in a while, and I went in with zero expectations, since I thought that the whole "English-first" concept looks kinda cheesy and the game's length further entrenched my doubts, but I'm glad I was wrong. Though relatively short (3-5 hours), Harmonia tells a story much more complex than it may seem at the first glance. That's actually a thing with all Key works: you have to read it all to really understand what authors meant, what ideas they were after. In that regard Harmonia is the same, since at the beginning I felt like main characters had very strange, unnatural personalities, and that kinda threw me off, but towards the end everything made sense. Good to see that after all those years at least some VN companies have that spark in them. Key is an example for the whole industry and I definitely recommend Harmonia to every VN reader out there: old and new alike.

25714337.review:
First few chapters are full of nonsense and forced drama, spending much more time trying to describe emotions rather than building/giving a reason for the MC/player to feel them. Not enough time is spent on character development, so some arcs feel lacking, as if they shouldn't even exist. But shit hits the fan shortly after and most of it starts making sense, if you didn't figure it out by then, as the game's filled with predictable post-apocalyptic tropes. The ending feels a bit abrupt, but the epilogue more than makes up for it.

Harmonia follows the usual key modus operandi and, despite its flaws, does not fail to punch you in the feels. However, you're not missing much if you've already played planetarian.

It might also include:
Great music, powapowas, military fanfics, one dimensional characters, high pitched voices, big-eyed waifus, sexual innuendos, half-naked nuns, no censorship.

Oh, and the vertical textbox was a really good idea for an easier reading/eye-travel, at least to me.

25711864.review:
[h1] Harmonia - небольшая история о взаимоотношениях между людьми и фиройдами в постапокалиптическом мире, образовавшимся по вине разногласний, о которых вы узнаете уже непосредственно читая саму вн (фиройды - роботы, внешне похожие на человека и обладающие присущими человеку эмоциями). [/h1] Внешне напоминает Planetarian, но более сильно углубляется в чувства и эмоции.
Довольно интересный сюжет, который медленно перетекает от юмора к драме (как это любят делать Key со всеми своими новеллами), с размышлениями о человеческих чувствах, действиях и их последствиях. Отлично подобрана музыка, которая кое-как способствует погружению в атмосферу слабопрописанного, пустого и неинтересного мира данной вн. Спрайты и CG выглядят очень годно, со своими отличительными чертами и красивой рисовкой, что я не могу сказать про задники, котороые мне не понравились (может они и неплохо нарисованы, но очень пустые). Основных персонажей всего 4, но каждый из них выделяется и имеет свою историю, которая в итоге интуитивно завершается. Драма здесь притянута за уши и получилось слабой, в сравнении с другими вн от Key (эмоции вызывает только наблюдение за отношениями ГГ и лоли-библиотекаря).
[h1]Итог: Довольно спорная визуальная новелла, но все ещё стоящая своих денег и поэтому я рекомендую ознакомиться с ней. Думаю, найдутся те, кому она придется по душе больше, чем мне. [/h1]

所以，下一个企划什么时候出来？

25699604.review:
Corta y bonita novela kinetica (no se toman decisiones es una historia lineal) Que trata sobre los sentimientos. Ambientada, digamos, en las mismas circunstancias que planetarian. Como viene siendo habitual por parte de key, lacrimogena, con un buen precio y ¡estrenada antes fuera de Japón que en el propio Japón!
Vamos a enumerar sus caracteristicas,
Pero, antes de nada:[list]
[*]Esto no es un "juego" es una "visual novel"
[*]Pertenece al genero de novelas kineticas es decir: no tiene elecciones sobre la historia, te conviertes en un mero espectador.
[*]Audio: japo, subtitulos: inglés, es decir, no hay español. Nivel usado: Medio con algunas palabras más técnicas.
[/list]

[b]Caracteristicas:[/b]
[list]
[*] Buena historia.
[*] Banda sonora adecuada (Y muy bien usada).
[*] Sólo con doblaje de 3 personajes: Shiona, Madd y Tipi. Eso sí, con calidad.
[*] Resolución original del trabajo: 1280x720. Se puede redimensionar sin problemas pero esta es su calidad original.
[*] Artwork: Los personajes son geniales, además el efecto de "coloreado a lapiz con moviemiento" le da mucha profundidad. Fondos: Algo simplones a mi parecer, pero con la animación en segundo plano (normalmente polvo desplazandose) les da más vida
[*] Sin animaciones: sólo tenemos a final de cuentas unos sprays "fijos", a la vieja usanza.
[*] Barata: 10€... 10 míseros € de precio base, no está mal.
[*] Corta: He tardado 5h en completarla tranquilamente.
[*] Lacrimógena, no llega a otras obras de key, pero estad preparados. ¡NO OS FIEIS!
[/list]

[b]Problemas: (a dia 25/9/2016)[/b]
[list]
[*] Hay que configurar de inicio la visual novel sí o sí para jugarla, sino no saldrán los textos
[*] Al meternos en "opciones" nos salta una pantallita de windows en japo (si entiendes esto felicidades) con las opciones "Sí" y "no"
[*] Deberemos elegir entre alguna de las fonts que tengamos instaladas en nuestro ordenador para que se muestre el texto, para ello hay que ir a opciones y darle a "sí" cuando nos salta la ventana japo, si le damos a "no" vamos a las opciones propiamente dichas.
[/list]

Recomendada, debido al trailer y la poco difusión que le han dado, mis espectativas eran muy bajas, y se han visto superadas con creces.

25699453.review:
请允许我以尽量客观的角度评测一下这款key社最新作。最核心的剧情部分我会放在最后说，让我们先看看其他部分。
首先是画面。说起画面大家肯定都不陌生了，桶妈的画风，（在桶妈离社的现在，Harmonia也算是她在key社的绝唱了），不过铅笔画的风格，配上shiona基督风格的衣服，tipi的洋装，还有末世的背景，显得格外的应景，并且相比之前的作品更有渲染气氛的作用，本作稍显压抑而凝重的风格，通过画面展现，不，应该说是传达得相当完美，我在游戏中看着这样的画面的心情一直有些压抑。尽管人体的问题桶妈到底没有搞明白，我还是要给本作的画面9.5/10分，画面上的表现对于key社而言算是相当惊艳的。
其次是音乐。key社的galgame卖的就是两样东西，一样是剧情，一样是音乐。本作的音乐依然没让人失望，作为一款小品作依然保持着较高的品质，虽然早已没有像黄金时期的Clannad及之前的作品那样曲曲经典，本作的大部分bgm也没法单拉出来单曲循环，但是在剧情的代入感上也是相当不错，另外，主题歌是本作音乐最大的卖点，towa no hoshi e 的表现非常耀眼，我觉得完全可以列为key社音乐的经典之一。此外，它的纯音版也非常的动听，即使不了解剧情，它的纯音听起来也非常令人动容。相比之下，ed的表现就黯淡很多了，相对明快的风格非常出戏，个人感觉，ed给我的体验是比较糟糕的。和主题曲简直是天壤之别。（当然，也可能是我没听进去吧）总而言之，音乐的评价，我给9/10，基础分8分，主题曲+2分，ed扣一分。
再次是系统的评价，没什么太多的我就不啰嗦了。新加章节系统方便读档，就是方便通关之后的人看想看的部分用的。gallery和music没通关用不了，稍微有点麻烦。操作系统感觉有些照搬rewrite的，不过反正是同社的无所谓。log文本里可以点击按钮从指定位置读档开始，虽然有趣，但是没什么用。总而言之，系统我就不打分了。一个小品作，没什么意思。
最后是剧情方面的评论，长度方面，我花了7个半小时左右来通关，当然考虑到语言障碍，实际的剧情容量大概在4个小时上下，容量较星之梦而言稍微要大一些，感觉似乎比rewrite的Terra线稍微短一些吧。[spoiler]剧情主要是讲一个人类男孩（被shiona取名为rei）来到一个机器人的村庄，学习人类的感情，并与shiona相爱的故事。总体而言除了机器人和人类的身份的揭示这一点比较出人意料之外，其他的部分剧情都比较老套。[/spoiler]love，family，这些概念构成了故事的核心——熟悉的配方，熟悉的味道。[spoiler]不过有了机器人身份这个伏笔，本来老套的剧情也显得有看点了不少，在第七章揭示谜底之后再返回去看madd的故事，还有shiona与tipi的白学现场（笑）也是相当不错的体验。[/spoiler]shiona对于rei的感情也描写的比较细腻，无做作之感，配合白学食用更佳[spoiler]（当然实际上不是啦，笑）[/spoiler]
然而即便如此，我依然认为，作为key社的作品，Harmonia的剧情并不能让人满意。或许相较星之梦，它也不算太坏，但是我个人认为，Harmonia显然是想讲一个更big的故事，星之梦讲的是[美]，Harmonia讲的是[爱]，或者说是[情]，无论是在中心上，剧情和场景的复杂程度上，Harmonia都显示出了很大的野心，而前半部分的质量也很对得起这个野心。问题出在后面。[spoiler]当游戏迎来终章，玩家本来以为是时候揭示shiona和rei的身世，同时拯救村民，把剧情推向最高潮的时候，剧情却以shiona突如其来的死草草结束，这种突兀感也使得shiona在终章对love的陈述变得苍白而僵硬更白瞎了好好的主题曲，也使得本可成为上佳之作的Harmonia沦为普通良作。[/spoiler]或许有人认为Harmonia输在剧情老套，但是个人认为，剧情没有老套还是创新之分，只有展现的出彩与平庸之分，Harmonia前半部分给了我一部上佳之作的呈现，但是非常遗憾它的后半部分非常不尽人意。综上所述，我给Harmonia的剧情8/10分。
结合以上陈述，我最后给Harmonia 8.25/10的评价，如果你一直很喜欢key社的作品，那么你不可能，也不可以错过它，只是它的确没有那么优秀而已。

25698742.review:
SPOILER FREE REVIEW~~

Harmonia is a beautiful game. Everything about the production is top-notch. From the visuals to the music to the voice acting, Key is in top-form here. The concept and characterization are both exceptional.

It's a shame that in the end, the story fails to deliver.

Which is unfortunate, because everything preceding the story's conclusion is amazingly well-executed. Our main character, who is desperately in search of a way to fix his absent emotions, is a compelling, earnest lead whose desire to help those around him fit his background. The upbeat, yet level-headed Shinoa is a perfect compliment to this goal. The reclusive librarian, Tipi, and the grumpy owner of a general store, Madd, both provide interesting contrats and conclusions one can make from Rei's straightforward, earnest attempt at friendship. Better yet, the story takes several surpsing, yet well-foreshadowed twists that will catch even the most savvy of readers off-guard.

However... The ending is emotionally tone-deaf. It has no respect for the events in the earlier portion of the story, presenting readers with an over-the-top resolution that is intended to be immensely satisfying, yet flies in the face of the grounded narrative the story tries to steep itself into.

Regardless, it's definitely worth a read. Harmonia is an experience I won't soon forget. However, in spite of it's good intentions, the ending casts an unfortunate hue on everything building up to it...

25687468.review:
[h1]Pros[/h1]
[list]
	[*][b]Soundtrack[/b] --- Memorable tracks that set the atmosphere for each scene.
	[*][b]Art style[/b] --- Excellent and sharp. The art in Key's works continues to improve. Subtle movement of the pencil lines in the character CGs is a nice touch.
	[*][b]Sound effects[/b] --- Effects play in scenes with some action that help enhance the atmosphere.
[/list]

[h1]Neutral[/h1]
[list]
	[*][b]Characters[/b] --- There are three main characters, not including the main protagonist. While two of them are charming and well written considering the limited time for development, the other has a very disappointing presence in the story. Their arc is quickly resolved within the first half when they could have had a major and more appropriate presence in the finale.
	
	As for the main character, his limited personality is due to plot constraints. However, there doesn't seem to be consistency with how he acquires emotions. Some of his epiphanies are repeated which makes the whole process seem irrelevant in the long run despite it playing into the main theme.
	[*][b]Writing[/b] --- For the most part great and up to the same standard as previous Key novels. In the final few chapters, however, when the plot becomes the main focus of the story instead of the character interactions, a certain group of characters' banter and the main character's internal dialogue is of noticeably lower quality.

	The main theme of the story is clear, but the message that the reader is told to take away following a certain event is openly repeated through the main character, who up to that point has remained neutral about the state of the world. It would have been best left to the reader to come to their own conclusions about that particular event.
[/list]

[h1]Cons[/h1]
[list]
	[*][b]Overarching plot & setting[/b] --- Not the main point of Harmonia. The main focus is on the characters. The plot itself is nothing new, and when it does become a driving force in the last half, it comes across as more extreme and jarring than what was needed to get the characters to their destinations.
	[*][b]Pacing[/b] --- While the length on its own (6 hours) is fine, the story pacing suffers as a result, especially towards the end.
[/list]

[h1]Conclusion[/h1]
Harmonia is a short, linear novel roughly [b]6 hours[/b] in length. It has everything that Key is renowned for; introspective characters, atmospheric soundtrack, and writing.

Harmonia definitely seems like a spiritual successor to Planetarian, Key's other kinetic novel that was roughly the same length. Perhaps too similar. The setting is the same: a post-apocalyptic future where robot servants are struggling to cope with the reality that the remnants of humanity are on an inevitable course for extinction. Even certain plot points are repeated exactly as they occurred in Planetarian.

What sets Harmonia apart from Planetarian are the characters. Whereas Planetarian centered on an odd couple, a soldier with no hope for a future and a girl whose mind was stuck in the past when humanity's future still seemed bright, Harmonia brings together a small cast of characters who must come to terms with their limited set of emotions as they interact with one another.

The missteps that Harmonia makes are a combination of short length and poor plot decisions. It might have been best to remove one of the characters entirely if only to give more time to the other two. The emotional impact of the finale is still there, just as it has been in other Key novels, but the events immediately leading up to it aren't satisfying and the resolutions to the characters are delivered in rapid succession.

Overall, Harmonia is still decent enough to check out if you're a fan of the genre or Key's previous works. Those who played Planetarian may find it a retread and will want to base their decision on how much they enjoyed that story.

Unless you're a major fan of Key who can't wait to read this story, it's best to [b]buy Harmonia when it's on sale[/b].

25683159.review:
Key's newest VN, Harmonia, has been a long time coming. When it was announced to be coming to Steam in English alongside CLANNAD's English release before being released in Japan, I was excited beyond belief. It was a very unexpected move on VisualArt's part, but a welcome one nonetheless. I knew I would be buying the game Day 1. But the game was constantly delayed due to various conflicts, until finally the game reached the quality VA expected from it.

So was Harmonia worth the wait? Well, let's look at the story first. A young Phiroid with no memories of the past awakes from cryogenic sleep, and seeks out civilization in order to find humans to serve. He stumbles across the residence of one Shiona, a priestess who takes him in and names him Rei. Quickly growing attached to Shiona's infectuous smile, he decides to help her as she sings to the townspeople and makes them happy. But there are some in the town who are not as happy, and Rei takes it upon himself to solve their lingering regrets.

I won't spoil the rest of the story, but while it does take some pages from previous Key games to make it more accessible to their audience, it does become something all its own. I can at least say that it's a shorter and easier read than Planetarian, although don't let that dissuade you from checking the story out. It's a hard sci-fi story that knows what it wants to do and accomplishes it fairly well, although personally, I've seen this same kind of story before on a few occasions.

Each of the four principal characters leaves an impression upon the reader, setting up an allegory to drive the novel's message of cherishing the human trait of emotion. Shiona represents happiness and warmth, Madd represents anger and stubbornness, and Tipi represents sadness and loneliness. Rei is the vessel that receives these feelings and emotions, learning through his own common sense what is good and what is bad for these individuals. Out of all the characters, Tipi is definitely my favorite, and it's not just because she's a loli~ :P

The artwork is unique among Harmonia's elder siblings, as it has more of a stencil drawing feel to it. I praised Sepia Tears for this same unique take on spritework, but Harmonia shows you how the professionals do it. The pencil gradient adorning each character sprite moves subtly, giving them an earthen, sketchy feel. Considering that the outside world is very dirty and polluted in Harmonia, this makes sense storywise. Itaru Hinoue's art in general has always been beautiful regardless of how old the game might be, and while she left VisualArt's a few days ago at the time of this review, this could be counted as a fantastic swan song to her days with Key. I wish her luck in her further endeavors, and hopefully this won't be the last time we see her work in a Key game.

The music is also worthy of note. With Key's in-house composer Shinji Orito and freelance prodigy Ryou Mizutsuki at the helm, the soundtrack is almost exactly what I expect from them. The music paints a picture of a desolate world that yearns to a single ray of hope, and it also captures every emotion Rei experiences while in the town or the outside world. I feel Mizutuski's pieces are much better composed than Orito's, and that's usually been the case even in Rewrite, but here it's especially noticeable. Not that Orito's music in this game is bad, but it pales compared to Mizutsuki-san's softer, simpler tracks.

Harmonia is not a perfect visual novel by any means, but it's a pretty darn good one. It has every right to stand with its elder brethren in the hearts of many a Key fan, and I'm glad it was brought over to English-speaking countries, even if it took a while to get here. If you are a Key fan, you likely already have this game. But for those who have no clue who Key is or have any passing interest in Key, do I recommend this visual novel to you? Almost certainly yes. Be prepared to cry, though. This is one journey you will not come back from emotionally unscathed. :)

25673599.review:
This review has no spoilers.

I've played Planetarian way back and oh boy I lost count how many tissues I've used in that novel. This visual novel has no choices so you just get to enjoy the ride in one way. Finished reading this. I must say I immensely enjoyed it. 

Story
- Post-apocalyptic setting about a boy who wakes up with no memories. Yes, we know it's kind of tropey or not that unique but the way the story builds up definitely makes up for it. The pacing may seem a bit quick as there are little to no fillers for this novel. I frankly believe it's enough for anyone to digest what's happening in the story.

Sound
- Normal ambient music that accompanies whatever is happening in the screen. And does it's job well.
- BGMs. I think this is probably the strongest part of the novel as it accompanies the scenes well. If you're familiar with previous Key games, you know what to expect as I think Key's in-house music people are the same people responsible for the music in this novel. I'd buy the BGMs as DLC if it were even possible.
- Character voices is fine. I'm not really into voices but I felt the voices done here were done well as it kinda ties with what's happening. No spoilers but you'd kinda get it if you trek the novel all the way through the end.
- It's not a Key novel if it doesn't have any orgel/music box in it. I'm a sucker for anything like those.

Graphics
- Well, graphics aren't really the main point of the VNs but I do like the character designs for it to fit in this novel. Itaru's doing the characters so there's that.

Characters
- I think this is the part where it doesn't shine as well as the other aspects of the novel. It felt like the characters weren't that fleshed out very well but nevertheless, it's just enough for you to know and care about them. I've mentioned how the novel has little to no filler so that may be a reason for it.

Others
- I don't think it's fair to compare this Planetarian as this one is more about feelings rather than Planetarian's tone of hopelessness (how I felt it). But they do share something common, I guess.
- I remember Planetarian to be longer. Though that may be because I used to read slower back then.
- No JP text. So if you happen to be an elitist or just take into consideration that JP text is a must, I'd advise you to skip this or at least wait if they will ever implement JP text in this novel.
- Can't complain about translation as there is nothing to compare to. Except the voices. Some stiff and awkward translation of the spoken lines but it gets the point across. Most of the translated voiced lines are fine as it is.
- Prepare some tissues.
- Playing porn games? I suggest you use your fap tissues for your eyes instead.
- For this price tag, I think it's fine for the story/experience you get. You'd probably avoid this if you're more into price per hour though.

tldr;
It's great, go get this
Or
Go get this if:
- You liked Planetarian
- You want to cry
- You want some easy reading
- To know what is love (insert unfunny reply here)
- Feel POWAPOWA inside

25668820.review:
在失去爱的世界中心唱响爱的协调曲
相当不错的作品，bgm满分，Towa no Hoshi e中毒了......铅笔风格的立绘相当入戏，飞扬的尘土也很有代入感，剧本本身也有不少出彩的地方。
因为玩的是英语版，以下评测可能涉及剧透，猜测，和个人的口胡，不想被剧透的小伙伴就略过吧。
[spoiler]首先从harmony这个单词入手，这不仅是和谐，协调之意，也代表了基督教中的四福音对照书，这部分大家先记住就行。
游戏的开头，是少年从机械中苏醒，看着自己的机械臂和散落一地的零件，少年意识到自己是个机器人，羡慕人类的情感，离开废弃工厂的少年，看到的是红色的，荒凉的世界，一片废土，人类在种族最辉煌的时候却遭到了人口的骤降（这部分后面会细讲）寻觅不到人类踪迹的少年倒在满天的风尘中......
少年苏醒时，碰到了眼前名为汐奈的少女，少女给自己取名为Rei，少女的笑容让身为机器人的自己，感受了名为温暖的存在。
为了报答少女，实践自己为人类服务的使命，rei开始修理音乐盒，期间邂逅了杂货店的大叔和一直在图书馆哭泣的提比。
帮助大叔寻找可以播放磁带的机器，rei在雨中固执地寻找，希奈的眼泪，让rei明白了什么是担心。
为无法救治伤员举办的葬礼，让rei明白了现实的残酷。
亲近提比的过程中，原来提比一直在等待自己的父母，此时希奈反常地变得刻薄，反复陈述提比父母死亡的现实，刻意分开rei和提比，rei第一次发出了怒吼，第一次知道了愤怒。
然而日常的完结总是猝不及防，废土的劫掠者很快发现了和平的小镇，并开始进攻。担心希奈的rei，第一次看到了名为人类的丑陋和冷血，面对劫掠者口中的处理，把小镇的居民当做物品，以及是自己引狼入室的现状，rei发出了怒吼，rei不冷静的举动，使得自己遭到追杀，希奈出现为rei阻挡了致命的射击，rei带着受伤的希奈离开了杂货店，来到了图书馆。众人决议回到教堂，在教堂里，本来rei想借机伏击一个劫掠者，即便费尽全力将劫掠者击倒，劫掠者却丝毫不害怕，劫掠者想要引爆手雷和rei同归于尽，希奈选择推开了rei，闪光中，鲜红的液体从rei的脸颊流过，是自己的血，血？自己不是机器人吗？rei一瞬间的疑问，在再次看到希奈的时候，达到了极点，希奈的手臂是机械肢..........
醒来的希奈向rei说出了真相，一切的真相。
整个镇子的人，除了rei,其他人都是Phiroid，也就是仿人类机器人。
最初赋予机器人情感，是因为人类希望机器人能更像人类，能让自己摆脱孤独。为了个人的私欲，就赐予了机器人情感，人类是何等自私的造物主。
仿人类机器人的出现，缓和了人类孤独的内心，然而，为了更好的服务人类，机器人都被赋予爱的感情，正因为如此，正因为活在充满爱的世界里，人类逐渐失去了爱，不论科学技术如何进步，却无法找出爱的公式。失去爱的人类，自然不懂得珍惜幸福，他们自持是世界新的造物主，认为旧时代的情感是落后而没有必要的，为了彻底毁灭落后的时代，他们无情地按动了大规模杀伤性武器的按钮，拉开了毁灭的序章。
不到5天，仇恨呼唤着更多的仇恨，人类不知道经历了几代的努力创造的曾经的辉煌，全部化为了尘土。
为了等待人类，为了等待曾经的partner，Phiroid开始模仿人类的生活，只是在执行潜意识的命令，Phiroid拥有情感却不得安息，这就是人类施加的罪孽。
rei想起来了小镇里碰到了的劫掠者，没有同情，没有怜悯，随意奴役，射杀Phiroid也没有一丝动摇，计较着得失的最大化，对自己的生命完全不在乎，这就是现在的人类吗？“比机器人更接近机器的人类”rei发出了感叹，rei愿意相信Phiroid是有生命的，是活着的。
总共86670张画，是提比忠实执行命令的见证，原来从提比的记忆开始，已经过去了200余年.......
提比因为缺少能源，在rei和希奈犹如父母的怀抱中陷入了沉眠。
希奈的机能状态也是每况愈下，终于连歌也唱不出来了，希奈胸口的弹孔宣告着希奈命不久矣，在rei的怀中，希奈睡着了。
rei痛恨这个人类敌视Phiroid的世界，并发誓要改变这一切，做到自己力所能及的事。
不知道过去了多少时光，希奈被唤醒，被那个人带往蓝天白云，重新充满爱的世界。
harmonia指的协调者，不仅是rei也是希奈，都是为了人类和Phiroid努力的见证者，不仅如此，harmony所指的福音是耶稣一生的记录，也是希奈一生的见证，就像耶稣经历了传道、受难、复活。希奈的人生轨迹也是相似的，经历了与rei的相逢，相恋，受难和最后被唤醒，是Phiroid的福音。[/spoiler]
最后就引用下原文You taught me how important feelings are
There is an everlasting song
And so I sang
The song that brought about the world someone dear to me had longed for
And I  will keep singing it...forever

25651703.review:
*Note that I haven't play long enough to write a review for this, so furthur edit wil be made in the future...

[h1] Summary [/h1] 

So where should I start... The story begins with you as an emotionless human android (Phiroids) awaken on an abandoned factory, wishing to serve humans to prove your own existence. BUT due to the population of humans declining in a rapid speed, the world is now a wasteland without any signs of life. Later on, something happened [b]*no spoilers*[/b] and you met a girl singing on the other side of door lay a chapel. You started to live with her, exposed to different kinds of emotions trying to learn what it makes you to be more "human"...


[h1] Should you buy it? [/h1] 

I would say YES, the VN itself focus on human emotions. From Happy to Sad, the color of emotions, how would you react to it and so on and ever. I really enjoy every second of it. The story definitely have its on depth and its definitely a must to all VN lovers "orange and powapowa" <3

*Additional note: The VN is being prior release on Steam before Japan, there is no reason to not give it a try right?
